'''Saffron Ringless Amanita''' ('''''Amanita crocea''''') is a species of [[Amanita]] widely distributed in [[Europe]].

==Description==

[[File:Amanita.crocea2.-.lindsey.jpg|thumb|left|Amanita crocea from Commanster, [[Belgium]].]]
* '''Cap''': The cap is free of rings with the [[Volva (mycology)|volva]] and has a diameter of 5 – 10 cm, yellow-orange in colour with an apricot tinge at the centre. It expands to become flat or sometimes convex at the [[Umbo (mycology)|umbo]], a  small raised central area.
* '''Volva''': Thick, white, at least 40 – 100 mm wide, saffron orange or a little browner than that in colour in the centre when fresh and paler at the margin.
* '''Gills''': [[Gills]] are free and cream in mass (sometimes with a slight salmon or pinkish reflection, and 2 - 3± mm broad.)
* '''Stem/Stipe''':The stem or stipe is 85 - 230 x 7 – 14 mm, 10 – 15 cm long and 1 - 1.5 cm in diameter, tapering, decorated with paler [[fibril]]s in a "flame" pattern, with the decoration later becoming orange or brown-orange (darker than the underlying stipe surface) with a membranous sack-like volva at the base.
*'''Spores''':The white spores measure (8.0-) 9.4 - 11.8 (-18.8) x (7.5-) 8.5 - 11.0 (-16.0) µm.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.njcc.com/~ret/amanita/species/croceas.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714185658/http://www.njcc.com/~ret/amanita/species/croceas.html |archive-date=2011-07-14 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/id_guide/amanitaceae/amanita_crocea.php {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226055532/http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/id_guide/amanitaceae/amanita_crocea.php |date=2010-12-26 }} Amanita crocea-Pictures, habitat and identification guide.</ref>

==Similar species==

{{multiple image
   | align     = left
   | width     = 100
   | footer    = ''[[Amanita fulva]]'' (left) in [[Bergen]], [[Norway]] and an ''[[Amanita caesarea]]'' (right) in Piacenza's mountains.
   | image1    = Brf.jpg
   | alt1      = Amanita fulva.
   | caption1  = ''Amanita fulva''
   | image2    = Amanita caesarea.JPG
   | alt2      = Amanita caesarea.
   | caption2  = ''Amanita caesarea''
  }}

It is similar to ''[[Amanita fulva]]'' (Orange-brown Ringless Amanita or Tawny Grisette) and ''[[Amanita caesarea]]'' (Caesar's Mushroom), belonging to the [[Vaginatae]] and [[Caesareae]] sections of [[Amanita]] genus respectively.

The edible Tawny Grisette is a [[basidiomycete]] [[mushroom]] located in [[North America]] and [[Europe]].<ref>http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5539.asp Rogers mushrooms.</ref> It was first described from [[Sweden]] in 1821.<ref>Kuo, M. (2002, September). Amanita fulva. Retrieved from the MushroomExpert.Com Web site: http://www.mushroomexpert.com/amanita_fulva.html</ref> It is easily confused with the 'Death Cap', though not as substantial. The structure is relatively flimsy and the hollow stem often breaks, even when handled very gently.<ref>http://www.wildaboutbritain.co.uk/tawny-grisette {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111904/http://www.wildaboutbritain.co.uk/tawny-grisette |date=2011-07-16 }} Tawny Grisette | Wild About Britain.</ref> It has fibres on its stalk usually.<ref>http://www.mushroomthejournal.com/greatlakesdata/Taxa/Amanifulva22.html Amanita fulva</ref>

The second similar species, the Caesar's Mushroom, is the [[type species]] (a species to which the name of a genus is permanently linked) of the [[Caesareae]] section of the genus [[Amanita]]. It has a distinctive orange cap, yellow gills and stem. Similar orange-capped species occur in North America and India. It was known to and valued by the Ancient Romans, who called it Boletus, a name now applied to a very different type of fungus. The word Amanita comes from Greek 'amanites' meaning mushroom and the word Caesarea comes from Latin 'caesarea' meaning caesarean, of, for, or belonging to Caesar, as this mushroom was highly valued by Roman emperors.<ref>Amanita caesarea. http://alphagamma.150m.com/Amanita_caesarea.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707055156/http://alphagamma.150m.com/Amanita_caesarea.html |date=2011-07-07 }}</ref><ref>http://www.eticomm.net/~ret/amanita/species/caesarea.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716104330/http://www.eticomm.net/~ret/amanita/species/caesarea.html |date=2011-07-16 }} by R.E. Tulloss.</ref>

==Ecology==

The fungi can occur infrequently between July and October in [[mycorrhizal]] with hardwood trees, particularly birch and beech in clearings. Its odour is sweet-smelling and it has a mildly nutty sweet taste.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/id_guide/amanitaceae/amanita_crocea.php |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226055532/http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/id_guide/amanitaceae/amanita_crocea.php |archive-date=2010-12-26 |url-status=dead }}</ref> It has also been reported from Iran.<ref name=bahram>{{cite journal|last=Bahram|first=M|author2=Asef, M. R.|author3= Zarre, Sh.|author4= M. Abbasi|author5= S. Reidl|title=Addition to the knowledge of Amanita (Agaricales, Pluteaceae) from Iran|journal=Rostaniha|year=2006|volume=7|issue=2|pages=107–119|issn=1608-4306}}</ref>
